block.p: FOR CHILDREN Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' about a bee who rejects toiling in the hive and decides instead to fly off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Staged by the Culture Project. Maya's story is told through rod and shadow puppets. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
FOR CHILDREN Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' about a bee who rejects toiling in the hive and decides instead to fly off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Staged by the Culture Project. Maya's story is told through rod and shadow puppets. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''I NEVER SAW ANOTHER BUTTERFLY,'' a new adaptation by Geraldine Teagarden and Sharon Talbot of the play by Celeste Raspanti about children in the Theresienstadt concentration camp who left behind a legacy of poetry, art work and music. Directed by Rebecca Taylor. Mazer Theater, 197 East Broadway, Lower East Side. Tonight and Wednesday and Thursday at 7; tomorrow at 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 3 and 7 p.m. Through June 4.Tickets: $12. Reservations: (212) 532-8887.

''LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD/LA CAPERUCITA ROJA,'' a bilingual musical play (performed in Spanish and English simultaneously), written and directed by Manuel Antonio Moran, tells the familiar story but with a twist. Riding Hood does not believe the wolf is a wolf, which leads the wolf to have an identity crisis. With Jose Lopez, puppeteer. Saturdays at 3:30 p.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m. through June 25. Los Kabayitos Theater, second floor, 107 Suffolk Street, Lower East Side. Tickets: $10; $8 for children. Reservations: (212) 260-4080, extension 14.

''SINGIN' IN THE RAIN, a production by Downtown Art based on the Hollywood musical about the Roaring 20's, complete with gallons of real water, and presented by actors 12 to 19 years old. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30; Sunday at 2 p.m. Downtown Art, 64 East Fourth Street, East Village. Tickets: $5; ages 18 and under, $4. Reservations: (212) 505-0835.

''THE TORTOISE AND THE HARE,'' Aesop's fables, including ''Androcles and the Lion'' and ''The Milkmaid and Her Pail,'' presented with hand and rod puppets and marionettes, adapted by Nicolas Coppola and presented by Puppetworks. Saturdays at 12:30 and 2:30 p.m. (through Aug. 26) at Puppetworks, Park Slope, 338 Sixth Avenue, at Fourth Street, Brooklyn. Tickets: $7; $5 for children. For children 3 and older. Reservations: (718) 965-3391.
Events

''ALL EYES ON IRISES.'' After contemplating the details of the petals, participants in a family craft workshop can create a folding screen inspired by floral traditions of Japanese art, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. at Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free from 9 a.m. to noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.

CATCH-AND-RELEASE FISHING (HANDLE WITH CARE). Releasing your catch is required when fishing in Central Park. The Central Park Conservancy staff will demonstrate how to do this safely tomorrow from noon to 1:30 p.m. at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue, (212) 860-1370. All ages. Free.

DESIGN YOUR OWN JOURNAL COVER WORKSHOP. Teenagers will learn how to design a journal cover using paint, markers and fabric tomorrow at 1:30 p.m. at the Queens Library, South Ozone Park Branch, 128-16 Rockaway Boulevard. Materials are provided. Preregistration is required: (718) 529-1660.

FLAMENCO BY CARLOTA SANTANA SPANISH DANCE COMPANY. The dance troupe performs on Sunday at 2 p.m. in the Harry De Jur Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side. Tickets: $5. Reservations: (212) 598-0400.

LATINO CULTURAL SERIES, a new Latino Cultural Series at Queens Theater in the Park, in Flushing Meadows Corona Park, off exit 9E from the Grand Central Parkway (near Shea Stadium) will go on through July. Of special interest to children today and tomorrow at 7 and 10 p.m. and Sunday at 4 and 7 p.m. is the comedy troupe Frivolidad in their show ''Tolay y Maruja,'' about two women who complain about everything. Tickets: $20, $25 and $30. On Sunday at 1 p.m., the Images and Traditions Children's Dance Group from Mexico will perform in a free program of traditional and popular dances from Mexico. Information: (718) 760-0064.

LOWER EAST SIDE FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS, tonight through Sunday, with performances of theater, dance and music inside and outdoors around the Theater for the New City, First Avenue and 10th Street. The focus will be on the the Lower East Side as a cultural center for the city, with appearances by celebrities, artists and filmmakers. Tomorrow's activities are aimed at children, with plays by youngsters, appearances by Sutton Gymnastics and Thunderbird American Indian Dancers and film and video screenings. Free. Also: an arts festival timetable is available at www.theaterforthenewcity.com. Information: (212) 254-1109.

NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY. Youngsters will have an opportunity to meet the author-illustrator Chris Conover, whose latest book is ''The Lion's Share,'' tomorrow at 3 p.m. in a program in which the author will talk about being an artist, share stories and draw pictures. For ages 4 to 8. At the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 621-0618. Also tomorrow, ''Story Songs,'' with Bob ''Bob-a-Loo'' Basey, who will encourage children to sing along to his flute and drums, at 11:30 a.m. at the Yorkville Branch, 222 East 79th Street, Manhattan, (212) 744-5824. For ages 3 to 7. Free.

''REMEMBER PLAYING MARBLES?'' Smooth pieces of colored glass -- shiners, aggies and cat's eyes -- have been present in most world cultures, including African, Aztec, Egyptian and Venetian. Weekends through July 2, the Prospect Park Alliance and Urban Glass are presenting ''Marble Millennium: Historic and Contemporary Marble Exhibit,'' at the Grand Army Plaza Arch Gallery in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, exhibiting more than 100 historical and contemporary marbles. Marble enthusiasts will conduct workshops on traditional marble games under the arch on Saturdays and Sundays from noon to 4 p.m. Visitors are asked to donate $1 or more for park maintenance at the park's major entrances. The No. 2 and No. 3 trains and the B41 and B69 buses go to Grand Army Plaza. Information: (718) 965-8954.

''SOYLENT GREEN,'' a 1973 science-fiction film directed by Richard Fleischer and starring Edward G. Robinson, is set in New York City in 2022 when food -- as well as everything else -- is in short supply. It will be screened as part of the Film Society of Lincoln Center's ''Movies for Kids'' series of science fiction films tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m. Recommended for 8 and older (several scenes might be disturbing to younger children). Tickets: $3. Walter Reade Theater, at Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street. (212) 875-5600.

STATEN ISLAND CHILDREN'S MUSEUM, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. Several workshops for children from 1 to 4 p.m. tomorrow and Sunday. ''Homemade Hygrometer'' today will teach youngsters how to become meteorologists and measure moisture in the air with a simple apparatus they can build from simple household items. ''Bugging Out Workshop,'' tomorrow and Sunday, involves creating a bug from paper, wood and cutouts. The museum has also organized a ''Bugs and Other Insects'' exhibition. Free with museum admission: $4; free for children under 2 and members. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Information: (718) 273-2060.
Exhibitions

''CAN YOU TELL ME HOW TO GET TO SESAME STREET?'' Most children know exactly how to get there: turn on the television set at the right time. An alternative route leads to the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Avenue, Crown Heights. This is where an interactive traveling exhibition (on view through Sept. 3) recreates the set of this PBS series, including the famous front stoop next to Oscar's garbage can. The Muppets on view include Big Bird, Elmo, Rosita, Bert and Ernie. There are also educational elements, and children can play with letters hung on hooks or write and post a message to a character, which will be delivered. Spring hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 2 to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free, with suggested admission: $4.

''A YEAR WITH CHILDREN.'' The annual exhibition organized by Learning Through Art/The Guggenheim Museum Children's Program, with artwork and writing by elementary school students from about 60 classrooms in New York City and New Jersey, as well as children in Mexico City, Italy and Spain, will be on view through June 18 at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street. Artworks include puppets, photographs, murals, quilts, videos and computer art. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; closed Thursdays. Admission: $12; $7 for students and the elderly; free for children under 12 accompanied by an adult. On Fridays from 6 to 8 P.M. visitors pay what they wish. Information: (212) 423-3500.
Zoos

WACKY WILDLIFE WEEKEND. Bizarre animals will be featured at the Staten Island Zoo, 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton, tomorrow and Sunday. Activities are free with zoo admission: $3; children 3 to 11, $2; under 3, free. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 4:45 p.m. Information: (718) 442-3101.
